docs.lead_paragraph: The deal has not been announced yet, but already there is no shortage of competing proposals for spending New York's $20 billion share of a reported $206 billion tobacco settlement: things like health care for the uninsured, stop-smoking programs and a cut in property taxes. For more than a year, since the first, ill-fated multistate tobacco settlement was announced, interest groups and elected officials here have been making plans for the money, which would be paid over 25 years. Today, with word that a settlement would be made final on Saturday and announced on Monday, the lobbying began anew.

headline.main: New York Counts the Ways to Spend

docs.abstract: Competing proposals already abound for ways of spending New York State's $20 billion share of proposed $206 billion tobacco settlement (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Rutgers University said yesterday that it will extend health benefits to gay and lesbian partners of its employees in an effort to settle a discrimination suit brought by five faculty members. The university's board of governors authorized the administration to renegotiate benefits with nine unions, which together represent about 10,000 employees, to offer coverage for the partners of an estimated 100 to 200 gay and lesbian employees, said David R. Scott, the university's lawyer.

headline.main: Rutgers to Offer Benefits To Same-Sex Partners

docs.lead_paragraph: These days, Representative Michael P. Forbes, a Republican from Suffolk County, has the pinch-me look of someone who was called a fool for betting his house on the ponies, and then, to the utter disbelief of his tormentors, won the trifecta. Two years ago, Mr. Forbes was the first Republican to announce that he would oppose Newt Gingrich's serving a second term as House Speaker. But Mr. Gingrich was re-elected, and Mr. Forbes, once a devoted Gingrich acolyte, became one of the most snubbed Republicans in the House. Still fuming over the incident, Mr. Gingrich was poised to strip him of his coveted seat on the House Appropriations Committee this coming January, House officials said.

headline.main: A Suffolk Congressman Comes In From the Cold

docs.abstract: Article on Repr Michael P Forbes, Republican from Suffolk County, NY, who opposed outgoing House Speaker Newt Gingrich's re-election in 1996, and was snubbed, and is friend of incoming Speaker Robert L Livingston; says Forbes is expected to become significant force within New York's House delegation with Livingston as Speaker; holds though Forbes is not running for leadership position, he is expected to become part of Livingston's inner circle; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Lawyers for Ira C. Magaziner urged a Federal appeals court today to clear him of a judge's accusation that he lied under oath about the work of President Clinton's task force on health care reform. In an hourlong hearing before the court, a Justice Department lawyer maintained that Mr. Magaziner, the chief architect of Mr. Clinton's ill-fated health care plan, had told the truth and nothing but the truth.

headline.main: Clinton Health Care Planner Asks Court to Clear His Name

docs.abstract: Lawyers for Ira C Magaziner ask Federal appeals court to clear him of Judge Royce C Lamberth's accusation that he lied under oath about work of Pres Clinton's task force on health care reform; Lamberth's finding of misconduct ordered Government to pay legal fees and other costs of doctors and consumer groups that had filed suit to gain access to task force meetings in 1993 (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: About 400 people drowned out rush-hour traffic on Columbus Avenue with blaring horns and screeching whistles yesterday afternoon in a protest of ABC's 10-day old lockout of its camera operators, technicians and editors. Union workers donned Pinocchio masks and one dressed as Mickey Mouse and wore a sign saying, ''America's No. 1 Corporate Rat,'' as dozens of speakers lambasted Disney, ABC's parent company, as greedy and unfair.

headline.main: In ABC Labor Dispute, Clamorous Picketing by 400 People

docs.lead_paragraph: State Farm Insurance Wins Savings Charter Approval Federal savings regulators have permitted State Farm Insurance, the automobile and homeowners' insurer, to use its network of agents to sell banking products like car loans, mortgages and certificates of deposit.

docs.lead_paragraph: EUROPE RUSSIA: YELTSIN MISSES BANQUET -- President Boris N. Yeltsin revived concerns about his health when he dropped out of sight on his first day back at work after sick leave and missed a banquet for the visiting Japanese Prime Minister, Keizo Obuchi. In an unrelated statement issued by his office, Mr. Yeltsin ordered Government leaders to put a stop to ''national and political extremism,'' referring to anti-Jewish remarks by a Communist member of Parliament, Albert Makashov. (Reuters)
docs.abstract: Russian Pres Yeltsin drops out of sight on first day back at work from sick leave; he misses banquet for Japanese Prime Min Keizo Obuchi; separately, his office issues statement ordering Government leaders to end 'national and political extremism,' referring to anti-Jewish remarks by Parliament member Albert Makashov (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-14 U.S. Buildup Continues As Isolation of Iraq Grows The United States continued to build up its forces for a possible attack on Iraq, which gave no indication that it was willing to back down and resume United Nations arms inspections. And unlike previous confrontations with Saddam Hussein, this one saw no last-minute efforts to mediate with the Iraqis. A1

docs.lead_paragraph: The state-run appeals process that allows patients in Connecticut to contest decisions by their health maintenance organization is not only a consumer safeguard, but it also helps people feel better about the insurance industry, according to a new study. Connecticut is one of 18 states that, along with Medicare, allow patients to appeal to an independent panel if an H.M.O. denies them coverage.
docs.abstract: New study finds that state-run appeals process that allows patients in Connecticut to contest decisions by their health maintenance organization is not only consumer safeguard, but it also helps people feel better about insurance industry (S)

keywords.value: HEALTH MAINTENANCE ORGANIZATIONS AND MANAGED CARE

docs.lead_paragraph: Ben Boucher looked in the mirror several months ago and decided that he did not want to be bald like his father. So, like millions of other balding men, Mr. Boucher, a 25-year-old animator in Montreal who is a long way from losing his hair, picked up a prescription for Propecia, Merck & Company's hair growth pill, and awaited the results. ''I can't say that I've actually grown more hair,'' said Mr. Boucher, who has plenty of long hair but has lost some around the edges. ''But Propecia has stopped my hair from falling out. And I'm happy for that.''

headline.main: The Elixirs Of Life Style; Drugs Can Spark Sex Lives and Grow Hair, So Why Are Some Sales Listless?

docs.abstract: Sales of so-called life style drugs, which help people feel better about themselves or improve appearance, have proved to be business disappointments; such disappointments illustrate how life style drugs can be much more difficult to sell than traditional medications; insurance companies seldom pay for them, severely limiting likelihood of repeat users; and consumers have come to expect more from life style drugs than they do from treatments for other ailments; drugs discussed include Propecia and Rogaine for hair growth, Nicoderm, Nicotrol, Nicorette and Zyban for smoking cessation and Viagra for impotence; chart; photo (M)
